newsitem.title: MOROCCO: Moroccan fisherman jailed for death of immigrants.
newsitem.headline: Moroccan fisherman jailed for death of immigrants.

text.p: A Moroccan fisherman whose boat sank carrying 26 would-be illegal immigrants to Spain was sentenced on Tuesday to four years in jail by a court in the northern city of Tangier, a court spokesman said.
Abdelaziz Fellah Boughaba, 27, was charged by the court of being responsible for the immigrants' deaths. He was also fined 500 dirhams ($57).
Boughaba earlier pleaded guilty and told the court it was the first time he had done "something like this".
Boughaba was arrested last week after he told police his boat sank in the Strait of Gibraltar while trying to reach the southern Spanish coast.

His vessel, the six metre (20-ft) Moujahid, had a legal carrying capacity of six. The 26 Moroccans, from Nador province on the Mediterranean coast, had paid Boughaba 4,000 dirhams each to take them to Spain, the court heard.
Boughaba told the court he left the northern town of Larache with the group on October 5, at around midnight towards the Spanish southern coast.
"When they saw the lights of coastal guard boats, the immigrants panicked...As they tried to hide, the vessel was destabilised, lost balance and immediately sank," Boughaba told the court.
The fisherman said he was the only one with a life jacket and had managed to swim ashore.
According to police, two bodies have so far been recovered near the Moroccan coast and eight others near the southern Spanish city of Algesiras.
His lawyer asked the court to free him, saying the Moroccan government was to blame for a policy of "marginalising" the country's young people so they sought to emigrate.
